messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:

>On Mon, 24 Mar 2003 08:09:56 -0500, "David Corbin"
><dcorbin@...> said:
><snip>
>
>
>> Well, as near as I can tell there are 4 choices on how something is
>> made
>> available:
>> 1) at construction
>> 2) as an argument
>> 3) as a global/singleton
>> 4) as ThreadLocal (similar to #3, but more flexible, certainly in the
>> web environment)
>> #2 is what I've been doing, and has created the smell
>> #1 generally doesn't work well, because the "something" may not be
>> very
>> tightly bound to the object being constucted.
>> That leaves #3 and #4. I have a long-standing global-phobia. Perhaps
>> it's too strong. #4 of course, isn't that differrent from #3 ( think
>> of
>> them as semi-global).
>> Have a missed a choice?
>>
>>
>
>Yes, the ones I mentioned on my previous response. Factories for
>instance.
>
But how do you get a hold of the factory that knows the correct way to
to create the object. The answer is one of the choices above (as you go
on to mention below).

>If there is behavior that you need in the class you are
>testing and it makes sense to break it out into its own class (as you
>have done) write a Factory that will give you back an instance of the
>needed class to be able to work with. The Factory could be globally
>accessible, if that makes sense or pass it in at creation time. Often
>times factories can give you access to several behaviors simultaneously,
>so if you need to pass in the Factory at instance creation time, you need
>only pass one or two. If they are globally accessible however (either to
>the system as a whole, or to a package, etc.), you obviously don't need
>to pass them in. I find that the factories I write are often static such
>that I don't need an instance of one to get an instance of the object I
>am after.
>
>Let's say I have a DBQuery that obviously needs a DatabaseConnection to
>do much of its work. The query doesn't need the connection for its full
>life-span, only for the short period of time in which to run against the
>DB, perhaps the rest of the time is doing maintenance work or creating
>Record objects to represent a row in the DB, etc. So, I make a Factory
>(in this case probably a pool) available from which the query can grab a
>connection when it needs it and then give it back.
>
But that factory is a global, and while factories have benefits, you
haven't gotten rid of the need to access global data, or pass in the
information in one of the other manners.

> The connection too
>has things that it may need only for a short period of time and can give
>them up -- i.e. a Prepared or CallableStatement. It can get the
>statement from a factory it has access to and then give it back when it's
>done.
>
>
>
